body: The **-A+z** modifier is listed as optional but without it we crash.  This rewrite reads in the entire data set first instead of record-by-record, and if no **+z** we determine the z-range from the data.  Closes #5516.

comments_content.body: Pinging @seisman.

I tried this script: https://github.com/GenericMappingTools/2021-unavco-course/blob/main/seismology/beachball-cross-section.sh.

This branch gives me this plot:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3974108/127089521-37c0b853-875c-4702-a9a7-6f342a5c8b91.png)

The shallowest and deepest beachballs are cropped because the automatically determined depth range is too tight. Can it be more clever about the depth?
In the animation 14 I also get the beachballs cropped. I have to add 10 (km; trough gmt math) to avoid it for the deepest one. The shallowest are cropped.

Yes, I noticed that too and thought about remedies.  Perfection would require us to add/subtract magnitude * scale / height to each depth and keep the extremes instead of just getting depth, since you may have an event that is not the shallowest but its size is larger so it would be clipped.  Something like that, no?

> Perfection would require us to add/subtract magnitude * scale / height to each depth and keep the extremes instead of just getting depth, since you may have an event that is not the shallowest but its size is larger so it would be clipped.

Sounds reasonable to me.
For me too. Although the text above of the shallowest beachballs will be cropped, right?

Let's reset this discussion a bit - I worry about setting a bad precedence by treating **coupe** in a special way.  In **plot** and other places one can leave **-R** off (as in **coupe**) and we determine an exact fit to the data.  If you are plotting any symbol then half of the most extreme symbols will be clipped.  In **coupe** there is also the label so this would get out of hand. GMT also has **-Re**[exact] and **-Ra**[uto] options as well.  If **-Ra** is used then we round the exact region outward.  Getting involved in determining symbol sizes and using that to change **-R** is a bit too much and cannot easily be doing in **plot**.

So my suggestions is that **+z** could take arguments **e**xact and **a**uto, with perhaps **e** being default.  With **+z**e we do exactly as this PR implements, while with **+za** we would employ the same rounding-outward algorithm that **-Ra** uses (_gmtinit_round_wesn_).  My only question is if **+za** should also affect the distance (x) rounding or not.  I think it should.

> So my suggestions is that **+z** could take arguments **e**xact and **a**uto, with perhaps **e** being default. With **+z**e we do exactly as this PR implements, while with **+za** we would employ the same rounding-outward algorithm that **-Ra** uses (_gmtinit_round_wesn_). My only question is if **+za** should also affect the distance (x) rounding or not. I think it should.

I agree, but instead of using **+ze** or **+za**, perhaps it makes more sense to use **+ra** and **+re**.

> Let's reset this discussion a bit - I worry about setting a bad precedence by treating **coupe** in a special way. In **plot** and other places one can leave **-R** off (as in **coupe**) and we determine an exact fit to the data. If you are plotting any symbol then half of the most extreme symbols will be clipped. In **coupe** there is also the label so this would get out of hand. GMT also has **-Re**[exact] and **-Ra**[uto] options as well. If **-Ra** is used then we round the exact region outward. Getting involved in determining symbol sizes and using that to change **-R** is a bit too much and cannot easily be doing in **plot**.
> 
> So my suggestions is that **+z** could take arguments **e**xact and **a**uto, with perhaps **e** being default. With **+z**e we do exactly as this PR implements, while with **+za** we would employ the same rounding-outward algorithm that **-Ra** uses (_gmtinit_round_wesn_). My only question is if **+za** should also affect the distance (x) rounding or not. I think it should.

Are **-Ra** and **-Re** documented? I had not heard about these options before.

They are well documented in my head, but apparently have not made it into the docs yet...
Modern mode only.  So I guess needs to go into several places.
Note: I will add the docs on -Ra|e now in a new PR

Update: Those who wish this to be perfect and include symbol size and label: Note that unless **-M** is used it requires the full calculation of moment and magnitude to scale the symbol size properly.  That is just too much work to implement for this minor adjustment.  What we could do is this:

1. I can do the quick/dirty z-adjustment for a Mag 5 symbol size given in **-S** and the optional label.  This gives an adjusted raw z-range that is pretty close but you may have some symbols of larger magnitude that happen to be at the bottom/top that will be only partially dealt with.
2. **+r** could take a few more arguments: **a** for auto will do the auto roundoff, i.e., the same as **-Ra.**, while **+re** would be exact [Default].  We could use **+rA** for the same as **+ra** except we let _zmin_ be forced to zero (surface of Earth) to avoid ranges like 5/400, for instance.
3.  +r could take optional _dx_ which would round the x-distances to a multiple of _dx_ [Default is raw distance range].
4. We could allow **+z**_dz_ which would round the determined range to a multiple of _dz_. This would override the auto for z if **+ra** is given, for instance, but **+rA** would still set _zmin_ to 0.

Thoughts?

I have finalized this PR.  I made a few changes to my plan above as I worked through it.  The auto-range handling symbol size and labels work pretty well, and exactly for **-M** (without **-M** I base my calculation on a max magnitude 8 event).  The **-A** option has been upgraded:

-**Aa**|**b**|**c**|**d**_params_[**+d**_dip_][**+r**[**a**|**e**|_dx_]][**+w**_width_][**+z**[**s**]**a**|**e**|_dz_|_min_/_max_]

I think this should cover all the bases.  The default as before sets the exact domain which now includes the size of the symbols.  You can then explore the auto rounding or fixed rounding or clamping.  Hopefully, @seisman and @Esteban82 can give it a test (see doc for explanations).  Here is the previous example:

![beachball-cross-section](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26473567/127727409-41d07833-4bbc-4c58-85f4-845c7df327e5.png)

According to the new features, what would happen if I have a maximum value of 300 and I use +za or +z50. If I understood correctly, I would get the same 300, am I right? 

So I wonder. Is there any way to extend the range of values by a certain percentage (e.g. 5%)? That is, if my data had a range from 100 to 200, then the range I get for the graph is 95-205. In this way I would get in the chart a small margin without data on the edges and this would be regardless of the values of my data. I hope this is understood.

I think +z50 would give you 300, but +za should extend it further.  Try it out.  Remember if you max depth actually is 300 then the max z I compute will be 300 + symbol-radius * inverse-scale which is > 300.  It would be great if you could play with this a bit and see how it performs.

I played a bit with the branch (I think, I am not completed sure if I installed well). In the previous example I try +z50 and I get this figure with NO error messages:

![beachball-cross-section](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17908951/127773273-63d4ca13-79a5-47a6-a006-0bba346ce965.png)

It there a bug?

```
gmt begin beachball-cross-section png
	gmt coupe meca.dat -Sa1c -Aa111/33/119/33+d90+w500+z50+r -Q \
		-JX15c/-8c -Bxaf+l"Distance (km)" -Byaf+l"Depth (km)" -BWSen
gmt end show
```

With -Za and -Ze I get this error message:

No, something must have happen on your end.  Bad gmt.conf? Nothing in coupe would affect basemap.

Try this script: It shows 12 different permutations of **+r+z.**  All look good for me.  I could not make a 4x3 subplot since coupe cannot go in a subplot as first command since there really is no -R for subplot to work with... I will make an issue of this - either we document or we find a solution.

```
#!/usr/bin/env bash
#
# Plot cross-section of beachballs
#
gmt begin
    gmt figure coupe_01 png
    gmt coupe meca.dat -Sa1c -Aa111/33/119/33+d90+w500+r -Q -JX15c/-8c -Bxaf+l"Distance (km)" -Byaf+l"Depth (km)" -BWSen
    echo "+r" | gmt text -F+cTR+f12p -Dj0.2c
    gmt figure coupe_02 png
    gmt coupe meca.dat -Sa1c -Aa111/33/119/33+d90+w500+ze+r -Q -JX15c/-8c -Bxaf+l"Distance (km)" -Byaf+l"Depth (km)" -BWSen
    echo "+ze+r" | gmt text -F+cTR+f12p -Dj0.2c
    gmt figure coupe_03 png
    gmt coupe meca.dat -Sa1c -Aa111/33/119/33+d90+w500+za+r -Q -JX15c/-8c -Bxaf+l"Distance (km)" -Byaf+l"Depth (km)" -BWSen
    echo "+za+r" | gmt text -F+cTR+f12p -Dj0.2c
    gmt figure coupe_04 png
    gmt coupe meca.dat -Sa1c -Aa111/33/119/33+d90+w500+zs50+r -Q -JX15c/-8c -Bxaf+l"Distance (km)" -Byaf+l"Depth (km)" -BWSen
    echo "+zs50+r" | gmt text -F+cTR+f12p -Dj0.2c
    gmt figure coupe_05 png
    gmt coupe meca.dat -Sa1c -Aa111/33/119/33+d90+w500+ra -Q -JX15c/-8c -Bxaf+l"Distance (km)" -Byaf+l"Depth (km)" -BWSen
    echo "+ra" | gmt text -F+cTR+f12p -Dj0.2c
    gmt figure coupe_06 png
    gmt coupe meca.dat -Sa1c -Aa111/33/119/33+d90+w500+ze+ra -Q -JX15c/-8c -Bxaf+l"Distance (km)" -Byaf+l"Depth (km)" -BWSen
    echo "+ze+ra" | gmt text -F+cTR+f12p -Dj0.2c
    gmt figure coupe_07 png
    gmt coupe meca.dat -Sa1c -Aa111/33/119/33+d90+w500+zsa+ra -Q -JX15c/-8c -Bxaf+l"Distance (km)" -Byaf+l"Depth (km)" -BWSen
    echo "+zsa+ra" | gmt text -F+cTR+f12p -Dj0.2c
    gmt figure coupe_08 png
    gmt coupe meca.dat -Sa1c -Aa111/33/119/33+d90+w500+z50+ra -Q -JX15c/-8c -Bxaf+l"Distance (km)" -Byaf+l"Depth (km)" -BWSen
    echo "+z50+ra" | gmt text -F+cTR+f12p -Dj0.2c
    gmt figure coupe_09 png
    gmt coupe meca.dat -Sa1c -Aa111/33/119/33+d90+w500+r25 -Q -JX15c/-8c -Bxaf+l"Distance (km)" -Byaf+l"Depth (km)" -BWSen
    echo "+r25" | gmt text -F+cTR+f12p -Dj0.2c
    gmt figure coupe_10 png
    gmt coupe meca.dat -Sa1c -Aa111/33/119/33+d90+w500+ze+r25 -Q -JX15c/-8c -Bxaf+l"Distance (km)" -Byaf+l"Depth (km)" -BWSen
    echo "+ze+r25" | gmt text -F+cTR+f12p -Dj0.2c
    gmt figure coupe_11 png
    gmt coupe meca.dat -Sa1c -Aa111/33/119/33+d90+w500+za+r25 -Q -JX15c/-8c -Bxaf+l"Distance (km)" -Byaf+l"Depth (km)" -BWSen
    echo "+za+r25" | gmt text -F+cTR+f12p -Dj0.2c
    gmt figure coupe_12 png
    gmt coupe meca.dat -Sa1c -Aa111/33/119/33+d90+w500+z50+r25 -Q -JX15c/-8c -Bxaf+l"Distance (km)" -Byaf+l"Depth (km)" -BWSen
    echo "+z50+r25" | gmt text -F+cTR+f12p -Dj0.2c
gmt end show
```

Note: I added modifier **+c**[**n**|**t**] which will do no plotting but simply report the region determined via **-A** either as 4 numbers _xmin xmax ymin ymax_ or as trailing text **-R**_xmin/xmax/ymin/ymax_.

I played a bit with Paul script. With the deepest symbols worked perfectly. For the shallowest, in some instances they were cropped like in the following figure (shallowest symbols range from 5 to 20). 
![coupe_03](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17908951/127799851-b6fe9f68-26a4-46d1-851d-27b6aefdef26.png)

However, then I try it with real data (japan-beachballs.sh) and a smaller size for the symbols (-Sd0.35c) is often used so I get a good figure: 
```

	gmt coupe japan.dat -Sd0.35c -Aa126/42/146/40+d90+w500+za+r -Q -C \
		-JX15c/-10c -BWSen -Bxaf+l"Distance (km)" -Byaf+l"Depth (km)" -i0-9
```


![japan-beachballs-sideview](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17908951/127800143-b51041e1-2b95-417c-9295-cecb93414a7e.png)

In conclusion, I think that in practice it would we worked fine.
Thanks @Esteban82, could you post the script and data for the first plot with the clipped shallow balls? I am curious as to why +za is not working there.

Sure Paul. I use this data
```

112 32 5  30  90   0  4  Strike-slip
113.5 34 10  30  60  90  5  Reverse
115 34 15 30  60  90  5  Reverse
117 32 700  30  60 -90  6  Normal
117 32 20  30  60 -90  6  Normal
```
and this script:
```
gmt begin
    gmt figure coupe_03 png
    gmt coupe meca.dat -Sa1c -Aa111/33/119/33+d90+w500+za+r -Q -JX15c/-8c -Bxaf+l"Distance (km)" -Bya50f10+l"Depth (km)" -BWSen
    echo "+za+r" | gmt text -F+cTR+f12p -Dj0.2c
gmt end
```

Thanks, I think it is because of my code doing this:

`GMT->common.R.wesn[YLO] = MAX (0, GMT->common.R.wesn[YLO] - dz);	/* But do not go negative into the air... */`

My thought was that one would not want depth to go negative.  But I can see if you have shallow quakes on a large range then perhaps we must, so I will take that off.  We still have the **+zs**[_arg_] modifier to clamp at zero so we dont need to above limitation.
Yes, that was it.  Update and try again and you will see.

Test it. Now it works perfect. 

![coupe_03](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17908951/127865464-b4caad76-f1a4-4ebb-863b-ece38b958b3b.png)
Pinging @seisman to see if he has time for a review so we can get this one done?

I'm trying this script: [https://github.com/GenericMappingTools/2021-unavco-course/blob/main/seismology/beachball-cross-section.sh](https://github.com/GenericMappingTools/2021-unavco-course/blob/main/seismology/beachball-cross-section.sh?rgh-link-date=2021-07-27T03%3A15%3A08Z).

1. `-Aa111/33/119/33` without `-R`: should report an error, but it crashes
2. `-Aa111/33/119/33 -R0/800/0/50`: should work, but crashes
~~3. `-Aa111/33/119/33` with the modifier `+ra` and `+re` affect both x and y ranges, but modifier `+r20` only affects the X range. I'm OK with the behavior, but it should be better documented if this is the expected behavior.~~
4. `-Aa111/33/119/33+r+z20`: the plotted depth range is about -5 to 65 km, but I expect it to be 0 to 60 km. Is it because beachball sizes are also considered in this case?

**EDIT:** 

- For point 3: I just read the documentation again. I think the documentation has already explained it clearly.
- For point 4: Just saw your comment in https://github.com/GenericMappingTools/gmt/pull/5525#issuecomment-890455369. It's OK to extend the depth range based on beachball size, but users may be confused by this behavior.
I will check and report back.
Thanks @seisman I fixed the two issues.

title: Let coupe detect range of depths as default y-values
